Award.AwardTitle: Expanding Career and Educational Learning in Information Technology (EXCEL-IT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Expanding Career and Education Learning in Information Technology (EXCEL-IT) project combines financial aid with advising and support services to low-income and under-served students at Green River Community College who are pursuing Applied Associate's and Bachelor's degrees in Information Technology. EXCEL-IT is awarding a minimum of 89 scholarships from 2014-2017 and is improving student access to careers as IT professionals in an area of high national importance via outreach and concurrent enrollment in K-12 school districts. Not only can project graduates meet employers' workforce needs more economically than foreign labor, but such careers deter reliance on government subsidies and empower graduates to be responsible citizens and taxpayers.

The technical merit of the project lies in its coordinated approach to increasing student retention and graduation rates through advising, tailored support services, and cohort-based activities. In addition, the project is producing a diverse body of well-educated and skilled graduates who are increasing the breadth of perspectives and backgrounds in the Computer Science and Information Technology profession. Moreover, the project is advancing scientific understanding of how four-year degrees pursued and obtained through community colleges can effectively broaden access to STEM careers for low-income and under-represented students. Relevant data and identified best practices are being shared through professional associations and external partners, which include a statewide IT workforce agency and a regional ATE Center, thus contributing to the larger knowledge-base about the undergraduate STEM education enterprise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Expanding Career and Education Learning in Information Technology (EXCEL-IT) project combined financial aid with advising and support services to low-income and under-served students at Green River College, pursuing Associate in Applied Sciences-Transfer (AAS-T) and Bachelors of Applied Science (BAS) degrees in Information Technology. The EXCEL-IT project served 63 students. Eight were AAS-T students, 53 were BAS students, and two participated in the project at both levels.

Four of the scholarship were Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander, three identified as Asian (two of those also identified as Pacific Islander), 6 identified as Black or African American, 1 identified as American Indian or Alaska Native, 7 reported as Hispanic, and 35 reported as white. The rest chose not to report their race or ethnicity.

Eight AAS-T students were enrolled in Green River College’s IT Systems and Security degree program. 29 BAS students enrolled in the college’s Network Administration and Security degree program. 24 students enrolled in the college’s BAS in Software Development degree program. 22 S-STEM scholarship recipients graduated from their degree programs. 39 students are still completing their studies. Two students left the program.

Since we have started our BAS programs, the enrollment in our AAS program has almost doubled. Our AAS completions have increased from 23 in 2013 to 37 in 2016, an increase of 60%.

In the 2015-2016 year, 70% of our Graduating AAS-T students continued on into one of our IT BAS degrees. The rest chose to use our AAS-T degree as a terminal degree and entered the job market.

In our BAS in network administration and Security, we had 27 students enter the first year, and 81% of those students completed within three years.

In our BAS in Software Development, we had 34 students enter the first year, and 73% of those graduated within three years.

Since we started our SSTEM scholarships in the Fall of 2014 (two quarters after our first BAS degree), it is difficult to attribute our growth to any one thing. Certainly the BAS degrees and the SSTEM scholarships together had an effect on our total growth, but it is not possible to determine the percentage of impact for each one.

Participating students received financial scholarships to assist with their costs of attendance. S-STEM scholarship recipients also received support services, such as advising meetings twice per quarter with project personnel; field trips to STEM employers; a student Technology Club; STEM competitions; and periodic networking “meetups.” BAS students were assisted by dedicated program managers who offered supplemental program advising; helped S-STEM scholarship recipients with course enrollment, financial aid, and other matters not specific to the IT program; and provided employment-related resources and counseling to students nearing graduation.

EXCEL-IT advanced scientific understanding of how four-year degrees pursued and obtained through community colleges can effectively broaden access to STEM careers for low-income and under-represented students. For example, S-STEM scholarship recipients rated as most influential visits or presentations by STEM industry professionals, cohort-based activities, participating in the college’s Technology Club, and attendance at industry conferences and events.

Of the 63 total students who received S-STEM scholarships, 22 are still completing their studies. 31 secured employment, 30 of them in IT-related jobs. 77% of graduates are currently working in IT occupations.

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2017
Modified by: Alan Carter

The rest chose not to report their race or ethnicity. Eight AAS-T students were enrolled in Green River College?s IT Systems and Security degree program. 29 BAS students enrolled in the college?s Network Administration and Security degree program. 24 students enrolled in the college?s BAS in Software Development degree program. 22 S-STEM scholarship recipients graduated from their degree programs. 39 students are still completing their studies. Two students left the program. Since we have started our BAS programs, the enrollment in our AAS program has almost doubled. Our AAS completions have increased from 23 in 2013 to 37 in 2016, an increase of 60%. In the 2015-2016 year, 70% of our Graduating AAS-T students continued on into one of our IT BAS degrees. In our BAS in network administration and Security, we had 27 students enter the first year, and 81% of those students completed within three years. In our BAS in Software Development, we had 34 students enter the first year, and 73% of those graduated within three years. Since we started our SSTEM scholarships in the Fall of 2014 (two quarters after our first BAS degree), it is difficult to attribute our growth to any one thing. Certainly the BAS degrees and the SSTEM scholarships together had an effect on our total growth, but it is not possible to determine the percentage of impact for each one. Participating students received financial scholarships to assist with their costs of attendance. S-STEM scholarship recipients also received support services, such as advising meetings twice per quarter with project personnel; field trips to STEM employers; a student Technology Club; STEM competitions; and periodic networking "meetups." BAS students were assisted by dedicated program managers who offered supplemental program advising; helped S-STEM scholarship recipients with course enrollment, financial aid, and other matters not specific to the IT program; and provided employment-related resources and counseling to students nearing graduation. EXCEL-IT advanced scientific understanding of how four-year degrees pursued and obtained through community colleges can effectively broaden access to STEM careers for low-income and under-represented students.
